text:
JACKLYN PETERSON: So today,
I have Dr. Kristin Sainani and Dr. Regina Nuzzo with me. Kristin Sainani is a
professor of epidemiology

at Stanford University. She teaches courses in
statistics, clinical research and writing, provides
statistical support

for clinical studies, and
writes about medicine, science, and statistics for a
range of audiences.

She authored The Health Column
Body News for Allure Magazine for a decade. She's also the
statistical editor

for the Journal of Physical
Medicine and Rehabilitation. And she co-authors a statistics
column, Statistically Speaking,

for this journal. She teaches the popular massive
open online course Writing in the Sciences on Coursera.

She was a recipient of
the 2018 Bioscience Award for Excellence in
Graduate Teaching

at Stanford University. And Regina Nuzzo is a professor
of mathematics at Gallaudet

University and lecturer in
population health at Stanford University. She teaches courses in
statistics, science writing,

and data communication
for students, clinicians, researchers, and other
working professionals.

As a freelance journalist,
she's covered topics in health medicine and
research, including preclinical and clinical
research, clinical trial

design, and research
rigor and reproducibility for publications such as
New York Times, Los Angeles

Times, Cancer Today, Scientific
American, and Nature. She received the 2014 Excellence
in Statistics Reporting Award

from the American
Statistical Association. And she gives workshops,
short courses, and keynote talks about
statistics, research,

and communication to
audiences worldwide. So thank you Kristin and
Regina for being with us today.

And I will go ahead
and pass it on to them for their presentation. KRISTIN SAINANI: Thanks, Jackie.

So today in this
webinar, we're actually going to discuss four
case studies that have important lessons for
the design and analysis

of clinical trials. And they actually have also
some pretty interesting interventions. Things like wine and hookworms
and some digital health

products. So Regina, this first case
study is super interesting because they actually
randomly assign people

to drink wine or mineral
water every day for two years. REGINA NUZZO: I'm wondering
how I can sign up for this.

Is it too late? KRISTIN SAINANI: The
study came out in 2015.

It did get some headlines in
the media, as you can imagine. Here's one of them here. It was specifically in
people with type 2 diabetes.

And they did claim to find
some health benefits for wine in terms of cholesterol,
lipids, and insulin sensitivity.

REGINA NUZZO: Which I think
is good for our Happy Hour tonight, right? KRISTIN SAINANI: I
totally want wine

to be good for your health. Absolutely. But hold that thought
because we are going to scrutinize those
findings in a minute here.

I do want to give the
authors a lot of credit, though, because as
you can imagine, it is not easy to do a
randomized trial of alcohol

drinking. REGINA NUZZO: I think this
is super important, Kristin, because I see these types
of headlines all the time.

And they're
observational studies. And of course, you
can't get causation from observational
studies because here's

where you're observing
people who have already chosen to drink wine or not. So if I'm the sort of person who
likes a nice glass of red wine

at the end of the
day, I am probably different in other ways
that also affect my health.

KRISTIN SAINANI:
That's exactly right. I mean, they've actually
found that wine drinkers tend to be more educated, they
tend to have more money

than non-drinkers. So how do you know
it's the wine per se versus these
other factors that's

influencing their health? That's why you need
randomized trials. REGINA NUZZO: Of course. KRISTIN SAINANI:
So let's actually

dig into the study
behind the headlines. This was called
the Cascade Trial. It was a phase 3 parallel
randomized controlled trial.

So phase III means
they were looking at the efficacy of wine. Parallel means everybody
was assigned to one group,

and you stayed in that group the
entire two years of the trial. The participants were 224
adults with type 2 diabetes.

They were all
non-drinkers to start because they wanted to see
the effect of adding wine to the diet. The interventions were five
ounces daily of red wine

or five ounces daily of
white wine for two years or you could have been put
in the control group, which

was five ounces daily
of mineral water. The study did provide the
little bottles of water and wine

However, it was not blinded. REGINA NUZZO: It's kind
of hard to do that. KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah. You can usually tell if you've
had a glass of wine, right, so

hard to blind. For the purposes of
this discussion though, I'm going to focus on the
outcomes of this study. So I went to the
report, which was

published in the Annals
of Internal Medicine and extracted all
of the outcomes that the authors reported.

These were the two-year
changes since baseline. And they labeled five of their
variables as primary outcomes.

These had to do with
cholesterol, lipids, and insulin sensitivity. And they labeled 10
additional variables

as secondary outcomes. These were other measures
of insulin sensitivity, cholesterol, lipids, and things
like blood pressure and weight.

REGINA NUZZO: Right. So Kristin, I'm seeing
five then primary outcomes. That is a lot.

Normally, we'd like to see just
one or two because every time you test a new outcome,
you're opening yourself up

to another risk of getting
a false positive there. So do they control
for that or adjust for that in their analysis?

KRISTIN SAINANI: No, they did
not do any adjustments to the P values for multiple testing. And the worry is, if you have
five primary outcomes, that's

going to greatly
inflate your type I error if you don't adjust the
P values, which they did not.

It. gets a little
worse than this though. I want to give the authors
a lot of credit, though, because they did
preregister their study

in clinicaltrials.gov. So pre-registration
means that you publicly release your protocol before
you even start the study.

And pre-registration is great
because it kind of locks you into the protocol. It helps researchers to
avoid the temptation later

of just changing everything
in their protocol after they see the data. So super important
to pre-register.

That means, though,
that their protocol is available in
clinicaltrials.gov. Anybody can go and
check, did they actually

stick to their protocol? So I went ahead and did that. Specifically looked
at the outcomes

that they had in
clinicaltrials.gov. So in clinicaltrials.gov, they
said that their primary outcome

measure was going to be
the six-month variable, not a two-year and
only one variable,

glycemic control, which is
actually a little vague. I think that might be
hemoglobin A1C, which

was not one of the
primary outcomes they had in their paper. And they only listed
one secondary outcome, which was CVD
status, which I think

is cardiovascular disease. You either have it or you
don't, a binary variable. REGINA NUZZO: So no matter
what, this does not even

match anything at all what
you put in the previous slide. This is completely different. They didn't do--

KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah. This is-- let me show you what
was actually in the published paper--

totally a mismatch, right? None of these are the same. So this is actually a practice
that we call outcome switching.

And it's not good. If you are allowed to choose
your outcomes after you see the data, well, that's
going to greatly increase

your chance of what
we call a type 1 error or a false positive error. REGINA NUZZO: Not good.

KRISTIN SAINANI: Not good. And actually, let's
go a little further and do a little thought
experiment here, Regina. So we can imagine if wine
does absolutely nothing,

if it has absolutely
no health benefits, we would actually
still expect to see

some statistically significant
effects in a study designed in this way. And we can predict
exactly how many.

So we need to know that
in the Cascade Trial, they used a 5%
significance level, meaning

they would declare
results statistically significant if the P
value is less than 0.05. That's very standard.

But it creates a 5%
type 1 error rate. And I'm counting
in the published paper there were at least 120
hypothesis tests that they ran.

So remember, five primary,
10 secondary outcomes. That's at least 10
variables they looked at. I'm sure they even looked
at things that weren't

in the paper, but at least 15. And remember, they had to do two
comparisons for every outcome. Red wine versus water,
and then separately,

white wine versus water. And they measured everything
at four time points. And they analyzed those
time points separately

rather than putting
them together in a single repeated
measures model. So that's a lot of
hypothesis tests.

REGINA NUZZO: OK. So to answer your
little pop quiz for me, how many significant
results would we expect?

First of all, you got that
120 from multiplying 15 times 2 times 4. And 120 is a lot of
hypothesis tests.

And you said the method
would allow for 5% of them
to be false positives. So 5% of 120 is 6. So six false positives.

There we go. KRISTIN SAINANI: Right. If one does absolutely
nothing, we're still expecting to see six
statistically significant

results. And this is idea that if you
torture the data long enough, they will confess to anything.

REGINA NUZZO: I love that quote. But I think sometimes,
people get maybe a little

confused about how did torturing
data lead to false positives?

It sounds a little strange. And I would like to think
of the role of random chance

in all of these measures. It played a big role in
like cholesterol level.

So every time I go
into the doctor, my cholesterol changes
just a little bit. So assume one does nothing,
but at one of these time points

like 18 months, you just
happen to have in the red wine

group, more people that have
lower cholesterol levels. So wine does nothing,
but it's going to look like it does something.

And so that's going to
come up statistically significant as a false positive. And the whole torturing
thing is like, you

know they're going to be a
false positive somewhere, so you turn over
all the rocks, as many as you can until, aha, you
find six false positives maybe.

KRISTIN SAINANI: Exactly. That's exactly right. And Regina, do you want
to take a wild stab

at how many statistically
significant results were in the cascade paper? REGINA NUZZO: I am
hoping it's not six.

Please tell me that not-- KRISTIN SAINANI:
It's actually five. And do you want to guess, which
five variables specifically

were statistically significant? REGINA NUZZO: There were
five primary variables, so I am sadly assuming it
was the primary outcome.

KRISTIN SAINANI: It was
exactly the primary outcomes. Three came out significant for
red wine, two for white wine,

never for both wines at once. And all of the
secondary outcomes were not statistically
significant.

REGINA NUZZO: So Kristin,
did it look like to you. It looks to me like they
collected a lot of information

about a lot of outcomes,
a lot of variables. Good for them. And then they
analyzed everything they could get their hands on.

And then after the fact, the
one that came up statistically significant, they put over.

In primary outcomes,
they ignored what they said they
were going to do in that pre-registration
and changed everything

after the fact. Yeah? KRISTIN SAINANI: I
mean, there's no way to know for sure
what happened here, but it definitely looks
like that's what happened.

They found all the
significant results and then selectively reported
those as the primary outcomes.

We actually call this
practice P hacking, where you're trying to
find significant P values and then selectively reporting
them or manipulating your data

to get significant P values. So the problem here is
that imagine if you're a reader of this paper.

You're going to
look at the paper, and you're going to think
the evidence is stronger than it is because
you're going to assume that those primary outcomes
were picked a priori.

Now, we've looked carefully
here and we know actually they weren't. So when I'm looking at
these results in context

and I'm saying, OK, 120
hypothesis tests, five of those came out significant.

To me, this is completely
consistent with chance. Like in other words, I'm
looking at that thinking, yep,

this is what you'd see
if wine does nothing. So to me, this
provides no evidence that wine is beneficial. And I'm really sad about
that because [INAUDIBLE]..

I want wine to be
good for my health, but there's nothing
in here to convince me this is what I'd expect to
see if just chance is at work.

Take-home points here. Randomized trials of
things like wine drinking, super important,
hard to do, but super

important because you
can't get causation out of observational studies. But the more statistical
tests you run, the higher

the chance of false positives. And this outcome
switching, this is a form of P hacking or cherry
picking that can

lead to false positive results. REGINA NUZZO: OK. Kristin now, this
is a point, as we're

going to do for all
our conversations about these case
studies, is rate the strength of
evidence 1 to 5 stars

like we are wine connoisseurs
ranking fine wine. So what's your rating?

KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah. Regina, I'm going to be able to
give the evidence here only one star because like said,
to me, this evidence

is exactly what I'd expect
to see if wine does nothing. So I'm not at all convinced
that wine is helpful for health sadly.

REGINA NUZZO: Yeah. So I agree with
you, but I'm going to bump it up to
two stars for me just because I love that
they had the audacity

to run a randomized trial of
drinking alcohol or drinking wine. So two stars for me.

KRISTIN SAINANI: Fair enough. REGINA NUZZO: All right. Switching over now, I'm
going to do case study 2.

Kristin, get ready. You gave us drinking wine as
a therapy for type 2 diabetes,

and I offer you and maybe
more palatable alternative, hookworms. KRISTIN SAINANI: Hookworms as
in the parasitic intestinal

infection hookworms? REGINA NUZZO: On purpose. Yes, in your body. Intestinal worms in
your body on purpose.

Yes. People were signing up for this
as part of a clinical trial. And as you can imagine,
the media enjoyed this.

Pioneering trial, it's a study
that will make many toes curl.

KRISTIN SAINANI: This is
definitely making my toes curl. And I think I will
stick with the wine-- thank you very much--

and not go with that one. REGINA NUZZO: All I
ask is that you wait until you see the evidence.

All right? Open mind. Open mind going into this. So I want to talk about
the details of the study.

But before I do that,
I don't know about you, but I was really curious why are
we even talking about hookworms

for insulin resistance, right? What is going on there. So I dug into the
intersection of the paper,

and it was kind of fascinating. I wanted to share this. So did you know that for
most of human history,

they think that parasitic
worm infections were pretty commonplace.

And we just lived with it. And researchers have
noticed that in areas where that is still
the case, these types

of metabolic lifestyle
diseases, type 2

diabetes and other
inflammatory diseases, they tend to be lower. And then when public
health workers

have gone in and tried
to lower the rates of the parasitic
infection, they have

noticed that those metabolic
disease rates have risen. Interesting.

KRISTIN SAINANI: So
that's super interesting, but I'm going to
look at that sort of with the same skeptical
eye as we were talking

about observational
studies of wine drinking because this is observational. And maybe the places that
have a lot of parasitic worms,

they also don't have a
McDonald's on every corner. And then about the time people
are coming in and eradicating

those worms, maybe
that's the time at which the McDonald's are
springing up on every corner. So this could just
be coincidental.

REGINA NUZZO: Right. Right. So that is exactly,
again, why we need randomized
controlled trials,

this time with very
brave volunteers who are willing to do this. So let's get into
some of the details.

Like yours, this was a two-year,
three-arm parallel trial. Yours was a phase 3 though.

And this is phase 1, 1B. And I think sometimes
people may not realize when they
see the headlines

that the goal of
a phase 1 trial is very different than
the goal of a phase 3.

It is not designed
to test efficacy. It's not designed to see
whether the therapy is actually

working or effective. Sometimes they call these
phase 1 trials a first in human trials.

And so the idea is just get
a small group of brave people and see if they can even
tolerate the therapy.

Like what doses
can they tolerate? Do they have to drop out? What side effects do they get? Then they use that information
to go on and design

these phase 2 and
then eventually phase 3 clinical trials where
they can look at efficacy.

So very different. I just wanted to
make that clear. Kris and I also
checked, of course, to see if the protocol
is preregistered.

It was in the Australian
version of clinicaltrials.gov. And they published
their protocol

in a peer-reviewed journal. And get this, they made their
data publicly available.

KRISTIN SAINANI: So I love that. I love when authors make
their data available because as a reviewer,
it's very helpful to me

to have access to the data
to be able to check things. It also gives me a lot of
confidence in the research

because the researchers
who are willing to share their data publicly, they
don't have anything to hide.

REGINA NUZZO: I love
the transparency. I feel like they got double
bonus points for that one. So they looked at 40
adults who all were

at risk for type 2 diabetes. Now, 40 sounds
small, but it's not unusual for this sort of
a phase 1 clinical trial.

And they randomized them
to one of three groups. You could either get a
dose of 20 hookworm larva,

a dose of 40 hookworm larva,
or a dose of Tabasco sauce.

So the worms are
microscopic, the larva. But they put it on
your arm underneath

like an opaque bandage so you
couldn't see what was going on. KRISTIN SAINANI: So the larvae
are absorbed through your skin?

That's gross. The don't eat them. They go through the skin. Yeah. REGINA NUZZO: Are
your toes curly now?

Yes. In the first six
hours or so, they do come in through your skin.

And you get maybe a
little bit of tingling or burning sensation, maybe
a little bit of a rash there.

Then, in case you didn't
know, the hookworms kind of make their way
through your system

and eventually
arrive at your gut. And then they use their
little hookworm heads to hook

on to your intestinal wall. And that's where they lay
eggs and make a new home

for themselves, set up a house. KRISTIN SAINANI: So
that sounds gross, but I'm noticing that they
had a really nice sham,

the control condition
is a sham intervention. Because that chili
pepper sauce, that's going to make you think
you got the worms.

It's a good placebo. REGINA NUZZO: Exactly. Exactly. And they did tell
them right, you

may be feeling a little
bit of a tingling. And I love the
sham intervention. I think it's super
important no matter

what the intervention,
but especially when that have this sort of ick factor.

So if you think that
you were randomized into the arm that
has hookworms, you

might be changing your behavior. You might lose your
appetite, eat a little less.

You might just feel sick to your
stomach just thinking about it. That's why it was
important to make

everyone think that they might
have gotten that intervention. So then they can
separate out what

were participants'
expectations or biases or what were they expecting,
unconscious or not,

and really find out what was
going on with the intervention. So I love that. The block randomization, that's
nice for a small clinical trial

because it helps ensure
better balanced groups. And they did blind
the participants,

as we talked about, but
also the researchers. So they helped to control
for those unconscious biases

or expectations
from the people that were treating the
participants and that were collecting data from them.

Nice. So here were the
outcomes that they listed in their registered protocol.

There were three of
them that were looking at that tolerability
and four of them that

were looking at the
efficacy, after the fact. KRISTIN SAINANI:
So Regina, we just talked about in
the Cascade Trial,

this is kind of a
lot of outcomes. But actually, this
is very different because in a phase
1 trial, we're

not worried about type 1
error because the point is not to evaluate the effectiveness
of the treatment.

It's to just look at
safety and tolerance. So it's OK if you
have more outcomes. REGINA NUZZO: Exactly.

It's different. It's different for that phase 1. I should say-- I should say, though,
even with that

in their secondary
outcome, they did control for multiple comparisons.

KRISTIN SAINANI:
Wow, I'm impressed. REGINA NUZZO: Yeah. I feel like they got they got
some extra points for that one.

Exactly. All right. So let's look at what
the actual results were.

Here we go. All right. Serious adverse events,
there were none. They were a little
worried about anemia

because apparently,
the worms can maybe eat your blood or something. No anemia in the
participants, but there

were some gastrointestinal
side effects in there. A little under half
in the hookworm group,

none in the placebo. Not unexpected. So this is when the
worms are in your gut.

So three of us like loss
of appetite, nausea. So three participants
were not able to take it.

They needed to drop
out of the study. But the other 24 were fine. And in fact, it went away.

It was only in the first
month, month and a half. And it went away without
any medical intervention

without any other
problems in there. KRISTIN SAINANI:
Regina, I'm noticing that the other adverse events,
the non-gastrointestinal, those

are actually pretty similar
between the hookworm and the placebo group,
which kind of shows you why you need a placebo group
because people get headaches,

things happen. As you mentioned,
you might feel icky if you think you have worms. So it's good to know
that actually that's

all really placebo effect. REGINA NUZZO: Yeah. Again, it was really good
that they had a good sham intervention here.

They actually call
that nocebo effect. A placebo effect is you think
you might have the intervention

and it might be
doing something good. The nocebo is you think you
might have the intervention, you might have bad side effects.

So they were able to
separate that there. OK. But mood.

Let's look at the mood. The mood was actually
slightly better in the hookworm group, Kristin. And this was during
the pandemic.

KRISTIN SAINANI: Well, I
guess they had a friend. They weren't alone
during the pandemic. [LAUGHTER]

They had little pets. REGINA NUZZO: [INAUDIBLE],,
you weren't alone during the lockdowns, right? You had someone to play
cards with and watch TV.

The completion rates were about
similar between the two groups. So that was good.

Now, again, they did not design
this to look at efficacy. But while they were there,
of course, they looked at it.

And they found that the
insulin sensitivity actually did improve in the
low dose group, got worse in the placebo.

So that was impressive. And the weight. Look at the weight. The average loss for people
on the low dose group

was about 5
kilograms at year one and it persisted on
through year two. KRISTIN SAINANI: 5 kilograms,
that's over 10 pounds,

so that's actually a meaningful
amount of weight loss, Regina. REGINA NUZZO: It is. It is.

They were very
excited to see this. And think that might help
explain my last observation

that all except for one person,
everyone else in the hookworm groups said at the
end of the study

they wanted to keep
their hookworms. KRISTIN SAINANI: They are going
to let them live there forever.

Really? REGINA NUZZO: Still
not convinced, right? I'm going to convince you
to come over team hookworm.

I think that this was great. So the researchers were very
excited about this phase 1

trial, which means now they have
information about tolerability. Not only can most
people tolerate

this therapy for two years. They can even maybe stand
it longer than two years.

They know what sorts of
side effects to expect and what the cost of that is. And they also got a little
information about the dosing.

For some reason, it looks like
the low dose group did better

than the high dose group. And they're not sure why. Maybe you just need 20
hookworm larva and not 40,

and that's it. So they're going to take
all this information, then, use it to design a phase
2 trial where they'll

dig a little bit
deeper into what's going on with the dosing. And then hopefully go on and
design a phase 3 clinical trial

where you can take a
whole bunch of people and see how the hookworms
perform in a big group.

Big group. Take home points here. Phase 1 trials are not
designed to look at efficacy.

It's the phase 3 trials
that look at efficacy. The phase 1 is really
looking at tolerability,

safety, those sorts of things. When you make your
data publicly available

and when you pre-register
your protocol, you make people
happy, you really

increase your trustworthiness. And doing a good job of blinding
with both the participants

and the researchers in choosing
a good sham intervention will help separate out any
unconscious expectations

or biases and let you
really focus on what's going on in the intervention. KRISTIN SAINANI: All right.

Regina, how many stars
are we giving that one?

REGINA NUZZO: I loved this. It was only a phase
1 trial, right? So they weren't
looking for efficacy,

but I think they knocked it
out of the park for phase one for what they set out to do. They did a wonderful job. So five stars for me.

KRISTIN SAINANI: I
have to agree with you. This was a really
well done study. So I'm to have to
give it five stars.

I am sorely tempted to take away
a star for the ick factor here, but I can't do that
in good conscience

because the evidence
is excellent. REGINA NUZZO: I really
admire your adherence to scientific principles.

KRISTIN SAINANI: All right. Third case study, Regina, not
quite as exciting as hookworms, but it involves a
digital health product.

And the idea here
was to give people competition that might
motivate them to engage

in healthier behaviors. REGINA NUZZO: I have to
say I'm pretty competitive,
so this might work for me. KRISTIN SAINANI: , Yeah me too. It just came out in 2023.

It did get some headlines. And they focused actually
on medical interns. So have you ever seen the
show Gray's Anatomy, Regina?

REGINA NUZZO: Yeah. A bunch of beautiful young
people overworked, right?

KRISTIN SAINANI: Right. They're on call,
they're sleep deprived. Somehow, the
characters on that show still have plenty
of time for drama,

but usually, medical interns
don't get much sleep. So the researchers
here, they wanted

to help interns to get more
sleep and more exercise. And so they put them
on teams to compete.

And they engaged
them in competition through an app on their phone.

So every week, the
teams were randomly assigned to either
be in a competition

either for exercise
steps or for sleep. And they were randomized to
face off against different teams

or they were randomized
to be in no competition. So the intervention here
is being in a competition.

REGINA NUZZO: OK. KRISTIN SAINANI: So they
would get a notification on their phone, something
like at 9:00 PM on Sunday

that would say something
like MGH surgery faces off against
Northwestern internal medicine

in this week's step competition. And then they'd get
reminders during the week.

Yale psychiatry is leading in
this week's sleep challenge with an average of eight
hours and 41 minutes.

REGINA NUZZO: That's way
more sleep than I get. What are you talking about? KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah, I
don't get that much sleep.

I doubt interns do, but this
was the example in their paper. Maybe meant for illustration
of the notification.

What the phone app
actually looks like. But let's now dig into the
study behind the headline.

So this was what we call a
micro-randomized controlled trial. And actually,
micro-randomization is something we talk about
in our course, Regina.

Super cool new technique that
allows you to randomize people many, many, many different
times during the study.

The participants,
they were in teams. Each team had to have
at least five interns. There were 191 teams.

And they were randomized
weekly to either be in a competition
for steps or sleep

or to not be in a competition. That's the control here. It was not blinded
because you did know if you were in
a competition or not.

They did give a small
monetary incentive. Medical interns don't make
much, so that can often up

participant engagement. They had two primary outcomes. So for the hearing the step
competition and no competition,

they were interested in the
average daily step count as measured by like a smartwatch
and the average step count

for the entire team. For the sleep competition, it
was the daily sleep minutes-- the average daily sleep
minutes was the outcome.

So a little bit more about
that micro-randomization [INAUDIBLE]. So a traditional
clinical trial, you can think about something
where maybe they're

giving a drug and
a placebo pill. It's actually very complicated. The logistics of figuring out
the randomization, getting

people the right pills,
keeping everybody blinded, logistically very tricky.

intervention that can be administered
on the phone like, HEY, you're in a competition
this week, guess what?

The phone can also
do randomization. So that allows you to randomize
the lots and lots of times

during the study. So week 1 of the
study, all the teams were randomized either to
step or no competition.

And then that was
repeated in week 2. They were rerandomized. And then it was
changed in week 3. And you could be
in all of the arms

at different times in the study. REGINA NUZZO: This is what I
love about micro-randomization, Kristin. So 50% of the time, they were
randomized to no competition.

That means half of
the time, each team was serving at its
own control, which

is very statistically powerful. It's efficient. It's a very efficient use
of sample size because--

especially if you have a lot
of variability between teams. So like, say, the Stanford
team is really good at sleeping

and really good
at walking around. Then you want to be able
to compare the effect of competition on top of that.

have your own control in there. KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah, exactly.
